title: Jeremiah’s Purchase and God’s Promise
shortSummary: Jeremiah 32 records the prophet’s purchase of a field during Jerusalem’s siege, symbolizing hope and restoration despite impending judgment. The chapter highlights God’s sovereign power to bring judgment and future blessing, emphasizing His faithfulness to His covenant people.
timeline: c. 588 BC - During the Babylonian siege of Jerusalem in the reign of King Zedekiah

keyCharacters.name: Jeremiah
keyCharacters.description: The prophet of Judah who receives God’s word during the siege and acts in faith by purchasing a field as a sign of future restoration.

keyCharacters.name: Zedekiah
keyCharacters.description: King of Judah who imprisons Jeremiah for prophesying the city’s fall to Babylon.

keyCharacters.name: Hanameel
keyCharacters.description: Jeremiah’s cousin who offers to sell him a field in Anathoth, initiating the prophetic act of hope.

keyCharacters.name: Baruch
keyCharacters.description: Jeremiah’s scribe who receives the deed of purchase to preserve it as a testimony.

definitions.definition: The legal right to buy back family land or property to keep it within the family, as commanded in the Mosaic Law.
Another name for the Babylonians, the empire besieging Jerusalem and carrying out God’s judgment.
A clay container used to store documents safely, symbolizing preservation through difficult times.
God’s unbreakable promise to His people to remain faithful and to bless them eternally.

outline.heading: Jeremiah’s Imprisonment and Prophecy of Jerusalem’s Fall
outline.description: Jeremiah is confined by King Zedekiah during the Babylonian siege because of his prophecy that Jerusalem will be handed over to Babylon, highlighting God’s sovereign judgment.

outline.heading: The Purchase of the Field as a Sign of Hope
outline.description: Jeremiah obeys God’s command to buy a field from his cousin Hanameel, symbolizing future restoration and the return of God’s people to their land.

outline.heading: Jeremiah’s Prayer Acknowledging God’s Power and Justice
outline.description: Jeremiah prays, praising God’s mighty works and justice, confessing Israel’s sin, and recognizing the certainty of God’s judgment and promises.

outline.heading: God’s Assurance of Judgment and Future Restoration
outline.description: God declares the coming destruction of Jerusalem due to persistent sin but also reveals His plan to restore His people after judgment.

outline.heading: The Promise of a New Covenant and Restoration
outline.description: God promises to gather His scattered people, give them a new heart, establish an everlasting covenant, and restore them to their land in peace.

application: Trust God’s promises even when circumstances seem hopeless, as Jeremiah did by purchasing the field during a siege.
Obey God’s instructions faithfully, knowing that His plans for restoration and blessing will be fulfilled in His timing.
Confess and turn from sin to avoid God’s judgment and receive His mercy and covenant blessings.
Hold fast to the hope of God’s everlasting covenant, which assures believers of His unchanging love and faithfulness.

keyVerses.text: Behold, I am the LORD, the God of all flesh: is there any thing too hard for me?
keyVerses.significance: This verse affirms God’s omnipotence and the certainty that nothing is impossible for Him, encouraging faith in His promises.

keyVerses.text: Behold, I will gather them out of all countries, whither I have driven them in mine anger, and in my fury, and in great wrath; and I will bring them again unto this place, and I will cause them to dwell safely: And they shall be my people, and I will be their God:
keyVerses.significance: These verses promise God’s restoration of His people and the renewal of the covenant relationship despite past judgment.

keyVerses.text: For thus saith the LORD of hosts, the God of Israel; Houses and fields and vineyards shall be possessed again in this land.
keyVerses.significance: This verse encapsulates the hope of future restoration and God’s faithfulness to His covenant promises.
